The depth method of relaxation is really just a hack.  The most
correct way to do it is to check every node from from one time step to
the next to see if they *all* stop changing within some epsilon.  

From what you are saying above though, I get the sense you just took
your old solution and relaxed it; is that true?  Training and testing
have to be performed the same way- so in other words the networks must
be trained to relax.  That way, you know that when you test later
you'll get the same results.  So if you train networks to relax (i.e.
if one can't relax in some given number of activations then penalize
perhaps) then they will learn to create recurrent structures that
relax into the solution of XOR.  I am sure someone in this group once
showed me such a network, with a single recurrent connection and no
hidden nodes...wish I could remember who it was.
